Text:

If you are curious if vista is still crappy, go ahead and try it out.

YW guys, I guess it could be used to generate a legit data trail if you were upgrading to win8 with the cheaper upgrade retail keys.  Of course win7 could probably do the same thing, but to each his own.

Anyway, you can tell I copy other torrent descriptions and edit them. I said that kb files were added with dism just before the kb lists. They were added with vlite.

If anyone wants to make an x64 version that will fit on a 4.37GiB dvdr, you could first install vistax64 with a usb drive, then install vlite and the waik (it gives you a link when you try to run vlite). Then you could remove the manual upgrade option and delete the net45 folder and $oem$ folders from the source.  I'm not sure if that would make it small enough to fit on a 4.37, but it probably would.

Anyhow, really the only difference between vista and win7 is the way they handle processes. Basically the kernel in vista likes to run the hard disk into the ground every time you modify any sort of system settings.  Once your system is up and stable, I'm sure it would be quite a bit less annoying.  I would still probably use one of those programs that unloads the useless services if I had to use this.

They really handled the system files much better in win7 and win8.

Do you also use the Windows Automated Installation Kit on Windows 8?

I've used nLite and vLite in the past (Windows XP, Vista respectively), however, they are a bit outdated.

onion, I suppose I could have if the operating system was worth spending the time to learn all the ins and outs of aik.  Vista just isn't worth spending that kind of time. I usually just use dism command scripting on win7 and win8, but the win8 apk is very similar. It wouldn't hurt for me to learn all about it when I get more time.

anarchist9027 vista is extremely bloated. Patching all versions I don't think would even fit on a 7.95GiB dual layer for just x64.

Plus the seed would die in a couple days. Noone really downloads vista anymore.

As far as the trimmed down ultx64, I'm sure there are a lot of ways to trim it down.  The problem is that every time you cut one service or option, a lot of people get annoyed.  There are ways to cut the iso down that don't cut the footprint down also.  I mean, I could remove the manual upgrade option.  That just removes the ability to upgrade from vista or xp.  The problem, like I said, is that it both makes people upset, and it doesn't reduce the footprint at all.

There are things that are disabled by default that you have to turn on to use that I'm sure most people could live without.  I tell you what, after I work on my xdelta conversion packs for win8 languages, I'll take a look at x64 win7 slimming and see what I can do.

Hmm... that gave me an idea... I guess I could make other vista versions updated and just release those versions as an xdelta patch of these isos in this torrent.  I'll give it a looksee but no promises.
na no more vista :D - a updated vista is what all need who need vista :P but a slimming w7 is more intressed =)

hey murphy, sorry I didn't mean, that you to make OEM version from desktop windows 7, I just want you to create(or RIP) the iso file from the reinstallation dvd from Dell's original OEM copy that comes when we purchase a Dell laptop. if you have it just RIP it from the original DVD or if any of your friends had purchased a Dell laptop borrow the DVD from them and RIP the original DVD! this is what I meant and wanted you to do, you understood now??

cantanion, the differences in the actual operating systems are not very big. The dell dvd just probably just copies a dell folder for the drivers.

I'm going to put this simply. No, I will not make a custom dvd specific to your dell dvd. There really is no benefit to using old dvd sources that some guy at dell slapped together by tossing a dell directory into the mounted install.  They make these dvds to tailor specific to systems, and that's just incompatible with trying to release operating systems to the masses.

I've been going over my xdelta options and although it is a very efficient way of releasing these sorts of things, I think I'll probably just try to go for an AIO release for January.  xdelta patches are great, but to be worth the effort, they need to be fairly small.  Sadly, although most of the files inside the installs are the same, they don't generate the same compressed data. I think I'm just gonna shelf that idea for now.

Plz make an OEM version +SP2 +IE9 x86 x64 + latest updates. Mainly Home Premium, but other editions welcomed. The main use would be for restoring computers to their original COA which happens to be Vista, since we all can't get refurbish licensing to fix client computers!

Worry not Vistaites, I will attempt to work in an AIO x64 and x86 version of vista with all the updates for January.  The hotfixes in vista are actually very small, even though there are quite a lot. To give you an idea: Vista hotfix totals are 775mb for both x64 and x86.  You'd think with so many hotfixes that it would be like a gig and a half for both, but it's not.  Windows 8 hotfixes dwarf these.. I swear, it seems like every month they release 100mb of hotfixes.

Anyhow, in January I'll try to limit the size to 7.95GiB or lower for the dual layer dvd people. If that is not possible with one release, I'll have to split them into x64 and x86 versions.  I should have the tools to accomplish the aio with x64 recovery and x64 sources directory thx to Josh Cell Softwares AIO maker.

Note that for the volume versions, they might have a strange eula because of being set to retail, but it's normal. It won't affect your files, just your install screens.
